name: Aeneas
description: Aeneas stands as the supreme hero of Roman mythology, a Trojan prince whose epic journey from the ashes of Troy to the shores of Italy established the divine destiny of Rome. Son of the mortal Anchises and the goddess Venus (Aphrodite), Aeneas embodies the cardinal Roman virtue of pietas - dutiful devotion to gods, family, and fatherland. His story, immortalized in Virgil's Aeneid, presents him as the legendary ancestor of Romulus and Remus and, by extension, of the Julian dynasty including Julius Caesar and Augustus. Unlike Greek heroes who sought personal glory, Aeneas sacrificed individual desires for the collective destiny of his people, making him the archetypal Roman hero.

origins.divineParentage: Aeneas was born of the union between the Trojan prince Anchises and Venus (Greek Aphrodite), who fell in love with the mortal while he tended cattle on Mount Ida. This divine heritage marked Aeneas for greatness and ensured the protection of Venus throughout his trials.
origins.trojanRoots: As a member of the royal house of Troy, Aeneas was a cousin of King Priam and second only to Hector among Trojan warriors. He led the Dardanian contingent in the Trojan War and was beloved by the gods for his piety.
origins.fatedMission: When Troy fell to the Greeks, Aeneas received a divine mandate to flee the burning city and establish a new homeland in the West, carrying the sacred Penates (household gods) and his aged father on his back.

mythologicalRole.trojanWar: Aeneas fought valiantly in the Trojan War, surviving multiple encounters with Greek heroes including Diomedes and Achilles, often saved by divine intervention. After Hector's death, he became the chief Trojan warrior.
mythologicalRole.flightFromTroy: On the night Troy fell, Aeneas rescued his father Anchises, his son Ascanius (Iulus), and the sacred household gods, though he tragically lost his wife Creusa in the chaos. Her ghost appeared to urge him toward his Italian destiny.
mythologicalRole.mediterraneanOdyssey: Aeneas led the Trojan survivors on a seven-year voyage across the Mediterranean, facing trials including the Harpies, the Cyclops, and a fateful stop at Carthage where he loved and abandoned Queen Dido at the gods' command.
mythologicalRole.descentToUnderworld: Guided by the Sibyl of Cumae, Aeneas descended to the Underworld to meet his father's shade, who revealed the future glory of Rome and the souls awaiting rebirth as Roman heroes.
mythologicalRole.warInItaly: Upon reaching Latium, Aeneas fought a brutal war against Turnus and the Rutulians. His marriage to Lavinia, daughter of King Latinus, united the Trojans and Latins, founding the line that would eventually produce Romulus.

feats: Escaped the fall of Troy carrying his father and the Penates
Led the Trojan survivors across the Mediterranean for seven years
Resisted the love of Dido to fulfill his divine destiny
Descended to the Underworld and returned

legacy.romanIdentity: Aeneas became the founding myth of Roman civilization, connecting Rome to the ancient glory of Troy and divine providence. The Julian clan claimed direct descent from Aeneas through his son Iulus.
legacy.literaryImmortality: Virgil's Aeneid, commissioned by Augustus, established Aeneas as the supreme epic hero of Latin literature, rivaling Homer's Odysseus and Achilles.
legacy.imperialPropaganda: Augustus used the Aeneas myth to legitimize his rule, presenting himself as the fulfillment of the destiny revealed to Aeneas in the Underworld.
legacy.westernInfluence: The Aeneid and Aeneas's story profoundly influenced medieval and Renaissance literature, informing Dante's Divine Comedy and concepts of heroic virtue.
